# ABO blood group system

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

"ABO" redirects here. For other uses, see [ABO
(disambiguation)](/wiki/ABO_\(disambiguation\) "ABO \(disambiguation\)").

"H substance" redirects here. For use in inflammation, see
[histamine](/wiki/Histamine "Histamine"). For hydrogen atom, see
[hydrogen](/wiki/Hydrogen "Hydrogen").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/ABO_blood_type.svg/410px-
ABO_blood_type.svg.png)](/wiki/File:ABO_blood_type.svg)

[](/wiki/File:ABO_blood_type.svg "Enlarge")

ABO blood group [antigens](/wiki/Antigen "Antigen") present on [red blood
cells](/wiki/Red_blood_cell "Red blood cell") and [IgM](/wiki/IgM "IgM")
[antibodies](/wiki/Antibodies "Antibodies") present in the
[serum](/wiki/Blood_serum "Blood serum")

The **ABO blood group system** is used to denote the presence of one, both, or
neither of the A and B [antigens](/wiki/Antigen "Antigen") on
[erythrocytes](/wiki/Erythrocyte "Erythrocyte").[1] In human [blood
transfusions](/wiki/Blood_transfusion "Blood transfusion") it is the most
important of the 36 different [blood type](/wiki/Blood_type "Blood type") (or
group) classification systems currently recognized.[2] A very rare (in modern
medicine) mismatch in this, or any other [serotype](/wiki/Serotype
"Serotype"), can cause a serious, potentially fatal, [adverse
reaction](/wiki/Blood_transfusion#Adverse_effects "Blood transfusion") after a
transfusion, or a contra-indicated immune response to an [organ
transplant](/wiki/Organ_transplantation "Organ transplantation").[3] The
associated anti-A and anti-B [antibodies](/wiki/Antibodies "Antibodies") are
usually [IgM](/wiki/IgM "IgM") antibodies, which are produced in the first
years of life by sensitization to environmental substances, such as food,
bacteria, and viruses.

The ABO blood types were discovered by [Karl
Landsteiner](/wiki/Karl_Landsteiner "Karl Landsteiner") in 1901, for which he
received the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1930. ABO blood types
are also present in some other [animals](/wiki/Blood_type_\(non-human\) "Blood
type \(non-human\)") such as [rodents](/wiki/Rodents "Rodents") and
[apes](/wiki/Ape "Ape"), including [chimpanzees](/wiki/Chimpanzee
"Chimpanzee"), [bonobos](/wiki/Bonobo "Bonobo"), and [gorillas](/wiki/Gorilla
"Gorilla").[4]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Karl_Landsteiner%2C_1920s..jpg/220px-
Karl_Landsteiner%2C_1920s..jpg)](/wiki/File:Karl_Landsteiner,_1920s..jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Karl_Landsteiner,_1920s..jpg "Enlarge")

Karl Landsteiner, discoverer of ABO blood system.

The ABO blood types were first discovered by an Austrian Physician [Karl
Landsteiner](/wiki/Karl_Landsteiner "Karl Landsteiner") working at the
Pathological-Anatomical Institute of the University of Vienna (now [Medical
University of Vienna](/wiki/Medical_University_of_Vienna "Medical University
of Vienna")). In 1900, he found that blood sera from different persons would
clump together ([agglutinate](/wiki/Agglutination "Agglutination")) when mixed
in test tubes, and not only that some human blood also agglutinated with
animal blood.[5] He wrote a two-sentence footnote:

> The serum of healthy human beings not only agglutinates animal red cells,
> but also often those of human origin, from other individuals. It remains to
> be seen whether this appearance is related to inborn differences between
> individuals or it is the result of some damage of bacterial kind.[6]

This was the first evidence that blood variation exists in humans – it was
believed that all humans have similar blood. The next year, in 1901, he made a
definitive observation that blood serum of an individual would agglutinate
with only those of certain individuals. Based on this he classified human
bloods into three groups, namely group A, group B, and group C. He defined
that group A blood agglutinates with group B, but never with its own type.
Similarly, group B blood agglutinates with group A. Group C blood is different
in that it agglutinates with both A and B.[7] This was the discovery of blood
groups for which Landsteiner was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or
Medicine in 1930. In his paper, he called the specific blood group
interactions as isoagglutination, and also introduced the concept of
agglutinins (antibodies), which is the actual basis of [antigen-antibody
reaction](/wiki/Antigen-antibody_interaction "Antigen-antibody interaction")
in ABO system.[8] He asserted:

> [It] may be said that there exist at least two different types of
> agglutinins, one in A, another one in B, and both together
>
> in C. The red blood cells are inert to the agglutinins which are present in
> the same serum.[7]

Thus, he discovered two antigens (agglutinogens A and B) and two antibodies
(agglutinins - anti-A and anti-B). His third group (C) indicated absence of
both A and B antigens, but contains anti-A and anti-B.[8] The following year,
his students Adriano Sturli and Alfred von Decastello discovered the fourth
type (but not naming it, and simply referred to it as "no particular
type”).[9][10]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/UkrArmyBloodGroupIII%2B2000s.jpg/220px-
UkrArmyBloodGroupIII%2B2000s.jpg)](/wiki/File:UkrArmyBloodGroupIII%2B2000s.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:UkrArmyBloodGroupIII%2B2000s.jpg "Enlarge")

[Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine") marine uniform imprint, showing the
wearer's blood type as "B (III) Rh+".

In 1910, [Ludwik Hirszfeld](/wiki/Ludwik_Hirszfeld "Ludwik Hirszfeld") and
[Emil Freiherr von Dungern](/wiki/Emil_Freiherr_von_Dungern "Emil Freiherr von
Dungern") introduced the term 0 (null) for the group Landsteiner designated as
C, and AB for the type discovered by Sturli and von Decastello. They were also
the first to explain the genetic inheritance of the blood groups.[11])

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Jan_Jansk%C3%BD%2C_1902.jpg/170px-
Jan_Jansk%C3%BD%2C_1902.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jan_Jansk%C3%BD,_1902.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jan_Jansk%C3%BD,_1902.jpg "Enlarge")

Jan Janský, who invented type I, II, III, IV system.

Czech serologist [Jan Janský](/wiki/Jan_Jansk%C3%BD "Jan Janský")
independently introduced blood type classification in 1907 in a local
journal.[12] He used the Roman numerical I, II, III, and IV (corresponding to
modern O, A, B, and AB). Unbeknown to Janský, an American physician William L.
Moss devised a slightly different classification using the same numerical;[13]
his I, II, III, and IV corresponding to modern AB, A, B, and O.[10] These two
systems created confusion and potential danger in medical practice. Moss's
system was adopted in Britain, France, and US, while Janský's was preferred in
most European countries and some parts of US. To resolve the chaos, the
[American Association of
Immunologists](/wiki/American_Association_of_Immunologists "American
Association of Immunologists"), the [Society of American
Bacteriologists](/wiki/American_Society_for_Microbiology "American Society for
Microbiology"), and the Association of Pathologists and Bacteriologists made a
joint recommendation in 1921 that the Jansky classification be adopted based
on priority.[14] But it was not followed particularly where Moss's system had
been used. In 1927, Landsteiner, who had moved to the [Rockefeller Institute
for Medical Research](/wiki/Rockefeller_University "Rockefeller University")
in New York, and as a member of a committee of the [National Research
Council](/wiki/National_Research_Council_\(United_States\) "National Research
Council \(United States\)") concerned with blood grouping suggested to
substitute Janský's and Moss's systems with the letters 0, A, B, and AB.
(There was another confusion on the use of figure 0 for German _null_ as
introduced by Hirszfeld and von Dungern, because others used the letter O for
_ohne_ , meaning without or zero; Landsteiner chose the latter.[15]) This
classification was adopted by the National Research Council and became
variously known as the National Research Council classification, the
International classification, and most popularly the "new" Landsteiner
classification. The new system was gradually accepted and by the early 1950s,
it was universally followed.[16]

The first practical use of blood typing in transfusion was by an American
physician [Reuben Ottenberg](/wiki/Reuben_Ottenberg "Reuben Ottenberg") in
1907. And the large-scale application started during the First World War
(1914-1915) when [citric acid](/wiki/Citric_acid "Citric acid") was developed
as [blood clot prevention](/wiki/Anticoagulant "Anticoagulant").[8] [Felix
Bernstein](/wiki/Felix_Bernstein_\(mathematician\) "Felix Bernstein
\(mathematician\)") demonstrated the correct blood group inheritance pattern
of multiple [alleles](/wiki/Allele "Allele") at one locus in 1924.[17] Watkins
and Morgan, in England, discovered that the ABO [epitopes](/wiki/Epitope
"Epitope") were conferred by sugars, to be specific, N-acetylgalactosamine for
the A-type and galactose for the B-type.[18][19][20] After much published
literature claiming that the ABH substances were all attached to
glycosphingolipids, Finne _et al_. (1978) found that the human erythrocyte
glycoproteins contain polylactosamine chains[21] that contains ABH substances
attached and represent the majority of the antigens.[22][23][24] The main
glycoproteins carrying the ABH antigens were identified to be the Band 3 and
Band 4.5 proteins and glycophorin.[25] Later, Yamamoto's group showed the
precise glycosyl transferase set that confers the A, B and O epitopes.[26]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/ABO_blood_group_diagram.svg/310px-
ABO_blood_group_diagram.svg.png)](/wiki/File:ABO_blood_group_diagram.svg)

[](/wiki/File:ABO_blood_group_diagram.svg "Enlarge")

Diagram showing the carbohydrate chains that determine the ABO blood group

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/43/Type_A_blood.png)](/wiki/File:Type_A_blood.png)

Student blood test. Three drops of blood are mixed with anti-B (left) and
anti-A (right) serum. [Agglutination](/wiki/Agglutination_\(biology\)
"Agglutination \(biology\)") on the right side indicates blood type A.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/AP-
Biology_Final_Project.svg/220px-AP-
Biology_Final_Project.svg.png)](/wiki/File:AP-Biology_Final_Project.svg)

[](/wiki/File:AP-Biology_Final_Project.svg "Enlarge")

There are three basic variants of immunoglobulin antigens in humans that share
a very similar chemical structure but are distinctly different. Red circles
show where there are differences in chemical structure in the antigen-binding
site (sometimes called the antibody-combining site) of human immunoglobulin.
Notice the O-type antigen does not have a binding site.[27]

## Alteration of ABO antigens for
transfusion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Alteration of ABO antigens for transfusion")]

In April 2007, an international team of researchers announced in the journal
_[Nature Biotechnology](/wiki/Nature_Biotechnology "Nature Biotechnology")_ an
inexpensive and efficient way to convert types A, B, and AB blood into type
O.[28] This is done by using [glycosidase](/wiki/Glycoside_hydrolase
"Glycoside hydrolase") enzymes from specific bacteria to strip the blood group
antigens from [red blood cells](/wiki/Red_blood_cell "Red blood cell"). The
removal of A and B antigens still does not address the problem of the
[Rh](/wiki/Rh_blood_group_system "Rh blood group system") blood group antigen
on the blood cells of Rh positive individuals, and so blood from Rh negative
donors must be used. Patient trials will be conducted before the method can be
relied on in live situations.

Another approach to the blood antigen problem is the manufacture of
[artificial blood](/wiki/Artificial_blood "Artificial blood"), which could act
as a substitute in emergencies.[29]

##
Genetics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Genetics")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/ABO_system_codominance.svg/280px-
ABO_system_codominance.svg.png)](/wiki/File:ABO_system_codominance.svg)

[](/wiki/File:ABO_system_codominance.svg "Enlarge")

A and B are [codominant](/wiki/Dominance_relationship#Co-dominance "Dominance
relationship"), giving the AB [phenotype](/wiki/Phenotype "Phenotype").

Blood groups are inherited from both parents. The ABO blood type is controlled
by a single [gene](/wiki/Gene "Gene") (the [ABO gene](/wiki/ABO_\(gene\) "ABO
\(gene\)")) with three types of [alleles](/wiki/Allele "Allele") inferred from
[classical genetics](/wiki/Classical_genetics "Classical genetics"): _i_ , _I
A_, and _I B_. The _I_ designation stands for **isoagglutinogen** , another
term for [antigen](/wiki/Antigen "Antigen").[30] The gene encodes a
[glycosyltransferase](/wiki/Glycosyltransferase "Glycosyltransferase")—that
is, an [enzyme](/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme") that modifies the
[carbohydrate](/wiki/Carbohydrate "Carbohydrate") content of the [red blood
cell](/wiki/Red_blood_cell "Red blood cell") antigens. The gene is located on
the long arm of the [ninth chromosome](/wiki/Chromosome_9_\(human\)
"Chromosome 9 \(human\)") (9q34).

The _I A_ allele gives type A, _I B_ gives type B, and _i_ gives type O. As
both _I A_ and _I B_ are dominant over _i_ , only _ii_ people have type O
blood. Individuals with _I AIA_ or _I Ai_ have type A blood, and individuals
with _I BIB_ or _I Bi_ have type B. _I AIB_ people have both
[phenotypes](/wiki/Phenotype "Phenotype"), because A and B express a special
dominance relationship: [codominance](/wiki/Dominance_relationship#Co-
dominance "Dominance relationship"), which means that type A and B parents can
have an AB child. A couple with type A and type B can also have a type O child
if they are both heterozygous (_I Bi_,_I Ai_) The _[cis-AB](/wiki/Cis_AB "Cis
AB")_ phenotype has a single enzyme that creates both A and B antigens. The
resulting red blood cells do not usually express A or B antigen at the same
level that would be expected on common group A1 or B red blood cells, which
can help solve the problem of an apparently genetically impossible blood
group.[31]

**Blood group inheritance**  
---  
Blood type  |  | **O** | **A** | **B** | **AB**  
| Genotype  | **_ii_ (OO)** | **_I Ai_ (AO)** | **_I AIA_ (AA)** | **_I Bi_ (BO)** | **_I BIB_ (BB)** | **_I AIB_ (AB)**  
**O** | **_ii_ (OO)** | O  
OO OO OO OO | O or A  
AO OO AO OO | A  
AO AO AO AO | O or B  
BO OO BO OO | B  
BO BO BO BO | A or B  
AO BO AO BO  
**A** | **_I Ai_ (AO)** | O or A  
AO AO OO OO | O or A  
AA AO AO OO | A  
AA AA AO AO | O, A, B or AB  
AB AO BO OO | B or AB  
AB AB BO BO | A, B or AB  
AA AB AO BO  
**_I AIA_ (AA)** | A  
AO AO AO AO | A  
AA AO AA AO | A  
AA AA AA AA | A or AB  
AB AO AB AO | AB  
AB AB AB AB | A or AB  
AA AB AA AB  
**B** | **_I Bi_ (BO)** | O or B  
BO BO OO OO | O, A, B or AB  
AB BO AO OO | A or AB  
AB AB AO AO | O or B  
BB BO BO OO | B

**_I BIB_ (BB)** | B  
BO BO BO BO | B or AB

The table above summarizes the various blood groups that children may inherit
from their parents.[32][33] Genotypes are shown in the second column and in
small print for the offspring: AO and AA both test as type A; BO and BB test
as type B. The four possibilities represent the combinations obtained when one
allele is taken from each parent; each has a 25% chance, but some occur more
than once.

**Blood group inheritance by phenotype only**  
---  
Blood type  | **O** | **A** | **B** | **AB**  
**O** | O  | O or A  | O or B  | A or B   
**A** | O or A  | O or A  | O, A, B or AB  | A, B or AB   
**B** | O or B  | O, A, B or AB  | O or B  | A, B or AB   
**AB** | A or B  | A, B or AB  | A, B or AB  | A, B or AB   
  
Historically, ABO blood tests were used in [paternity
testing](/wiki/DNA_paternity_testing "DNA paternity testing"), but in 1957
only 50% of American men falsely accused were able to use them as evidence
against paternity.[34] Occasionally, the blood types of children are not
consistent with expectations—for example, a type O child can be born to an AB
parent—due to rare situations, such as [Bombay
phenotype](/wiki/Bombay_phenotype "Bombay phenotype") and [cis
AB](/wiki/Cis_AB "Cis AB").[35]

###
Subgroups[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Subgroups")]

The A blood type contains about 20 subgroups, of which A1 and A2 are the most
common (over 99%). A1 makes up about 80% of all A-type blood, with A2 making
up almost all of the rest.[36] These two subgroups are not always
interchangeable as far as transfusion is concerned, as some A2 individuals
produce antibodies against the A1 antigen. Complications can sometimes arise
in rare cases when typing the blood.[36]

With the development of [DNA sequencing](/wiki/DNA_sequencing "DNA
sequencing"), it has been possible to identify a much larger number of alleles
at the ABO locus, each of which can be categorized as A, B, or O in terms of
the reaction to transfusion, but which can be distinguished by variations in
the [DNA](/wiki/DNA "DNA") sequence. There are six common
[alleles](/wiki/Allele "Allele") in white individuals of the [ABO
gene](/wiki/ABO_gene "ABO gene") that produce one's blood type:[37][38]

A | B | O   
---|---|---  
_A101_ (A1)  
_A201_ (A2)  | _B101_ (B1)  | _O01_ (O1)  
_O02_ (O1v)  
_O03_ (O2)  
  
The same study also identified 18 rare alleles, which generally have a weaker
glycosylation activity. People with weak alleles of A can sometimes express
anti-A antibodies, though these are usually not clinically significant as they
do not stably interact with the antigen at body temperature.[39]

[Cis AB](/wiki/Cis_AB "Cis AB") is another rare variant, in which A and B
genes are transmitted together from a single parent.

### Distribution and evolutionary
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Distribution and evolutionary history")]

Main article: [Blood type distribution by
country](/wiki/Blood_type_distribution_by_country "Blood type distribution by
country")

The distribution of the blood groups A, B, O and AB varies across the world
according to the population. There are also variations in blood type
distribution within human subpopulations.

In the UK, the distribution of blood type frequencies through the population
still shows some correlation to the distribution of
[placenames](/wiki/Toponymy "Toponymy") and to the successive invasions and
migrations including [Norsemen](/wiki/Norsemen "Norsemen"),
[Danes](/wiki/Danes_\(Germanic_tribe\) "Danes \(Germanic tribe\)"),
[Saxons](/wiki/Saxons "Saxons"), [Celts](/wiki/Celts "Celts"), and
[Normans](/wiki/Normans "Normans") who contributed the
[morphemes](/wiki/Morpheme "Morpheme") to the placenames and the
[genes](/wiki/Gene "Gene") to the population.[40]

The two common O alleles, O01 and O02, share their first 261
[nucleotides](/wiki/Nucleotide "Nucleotide") with the group A allele A01.[41]
However, unlike the group A allele, a [guanosine](/wiki/Guanosine "Guanosine")
base is subsequently deleted. A premature [stop codon](/wiki/Stop_codon "Stop
codon") results from this [frame-shift mutation](/wiki/Frame-shift_mutation
"Frame-shift mutation"). This variant is found worldwide, and likely predates
human migration from [Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa"). The O01 allele is
considered to predate the O02 allele.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Some evolutionary biologists theorize that there are four main lineages of the
ABO gene and that mutations creating type O have occurred at least three times
in humans.[42] From oldest to youngest, these lineages comprise the following
alleles: _A101/A201/O09_ , _B101_ , _O02_ and _O01_. The continued presence of
the O alleles is hypothesized to be the result of [balancing
selection](/wiki/Balancing_selection "Balancing selection").[42] Both theories
contradict the previously held theory that type O blood evolved
first.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

### Origin
theories[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Origin theories")]

It is possible that food and environmental antigens (bacterial, viral, or
plant antigens) have [epitopes](/wiki/Epitope "Epitope") similar enough to A
and B glycoprotein antigens. The antibodies created against these
environmental antigens in the first years of life can cross-react with ABO-
incompatible red blood cells that it comes in contact with during blood
transfusion later in life. Anti-A antibodies are hypothesized to originate
from immune response towards [influenza virus](/wiki/Influenza_virus
"Influenza virus"), whose epitopes are similar enough to the α-D-N-
galactosamine on the A glycoprotein to be able to elicit a cross-reaction.
Anti-B antibodies are hypothesized to originate from antibodies produced
against [Gram-negative bacteria](/wiki/Gram-negative_bacteria "Gram-negative
bacteria"), such as _[E. coli](/wiki/Escherichia_coli "Escherichia coli")_ ,
cross-reacting with the α-D-galactose on the B glycoprotein.[43]

However, it is more likely that the force driving evolution of allele
diversity is simply negative frequency-dependent selection; cells with rare
variants of membrane antigens are more easily distinguished by the immune
system from pathogens carrying antigens from other hosts. Thus, individuals
possessing rare types are better equipped to detect pathogens. The high
within-population diversity observed in human populations would, then, be a
consequence of natural selection on individuals.[44]

HIV can be neutralized in _in vitro_ experiments using antibodies against
blood group antigens specifically expressed on the HIV-producing cell
lines.[45][46]

## Clinical
relevance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Clinical relevance")]

The carbohydrate molecules on the surfaces of red blood cells have roles in
[cell membrane](/wiki/Cell_membrane "Cell membrane") integrity, [cell
adhesion](/wiki/Cell_adhesion "Cell adhesion"), membrane transportation of
molecules, and acting as receptors for extracellular ligands, and enzymes. ABO
antigens are found having similar roles on [epithelial
cells](/wiki/Epithelial_cell "Epithelial cell") as well as red blood
cells.[47][48]

### Bleeding and thrombosis (von Willebrand
factor)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Bleeding and thrombosis \(von Willebrand factor\)")]

The ABO antigen is also expressed on the [von Willebrand
factor](/wiki/Von_Willebrand_factor "Von Willebrand factor") (vWF)
[glycoprotein](/wiki/Glycoprotein "Glycoprotein"),[49] which participates in
[hemostasis](/wiki/Hemostasis "Hemostasis") (control of bleeding). In fact,
having type O blood predisposes to bleeding,[50] as 30% of the total genetic
variation observed in plasma vWF is explained by the effect of the ABO blood
group,[51] and individuals with group O blood normally have significantly
lower plasma levels of vWF (and [Factor VIII](/wiki/Factor_VIII "Factor
VIII")) than do non-O individuals.[52][53] In addition, vWF is degraded more
rapidly due to the higher prevalence of blood group O with the Cys1584 variant
of vWF (an amino acid [polymorphism](/wiki/Polymorphism_\(biology\)
"Polymorphism \(biology\)") in VWF):[54] the gene for
[ADAMTS13](/wiki/ADAMTS13 "ADAMTS13") (vWF-cleaving [protease](/wiki/Protease
"Protease")) maps to the [ninth chromosome](/wiki/Chromosome_9_\(human\)
"Chromosome 9 \(human\)") (9q34), the same [locus](/wiki/Locus_\(genetics\)
"Locus \(genetics\)") as ABO blood type. Higher levels of vWF are more common
amongst people who have had [ischemic stroke](/wiki/Ischemic_stroke "Ischemic
stroke") (from blood clotting) for the first time.[55] The results of this
study found that the occurrence was not affected by ADAMTS13 polymorphism, and
the only significant genetic factor was the person's blood group.

### Disease
risks[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Disease risks")]

Compared to O group individuals, non-O group (A, AB, and B) individuals have a
14% reduced risk of [squamous cell carcinoma](/wiki/Squamous_cell_carcinoma
"Squamous cell carcinoma") and 4% reduced risk of [basal cell
carcinoma](/wiki/Basal_cell_carcinoma "Basal cell carcinoma").[56] Conversely,
type O blood is associated with a reduced risk of [pancreatic
cancer](/wiki/Pancreatic_cancer "Pancreatic cancer").[57][58] The B antigen
links with increased risk of [ovarian cancer](/wiki/Ovarian_cancer "Ovarian
cancer").[59] [Gastric cancer](/wiki/Gastric_cancer "Gastric cancer") has
reported to be more common in blood group A and least in group O.[60]

According to Glass, Holmgren, et al., those in the O blood group have an
increased risk of infection with [cholera](/wiki/Cholera "Cholera"), and those
O-group individuals who are infected have more severe infections. The
mechanisms behind this association with cholera are unclear in the
literature.[61]

### ABO hemolytic disease of the
newborn[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: ABO hemolytic disease of the newborn")]

Main article: [Hemolytic disease of the newborn
(ABO)](/wiki/Hemolytic_disease_of_the_newborn_\(ABO\) "Hemolytic disease of
the newborn \(ABO\)")

ABO blood group incompatibilities between the mother and child does not
usually cause [hemolytic disease of the
newborn](/wiki/Hemolytic_disease_of_the_newborn "Hemolytic disease of the
newborn") (HDN) because antibodies to the ABO blood groups are usually of the
[IgM](/wiki/IgM "IgM") type, which do not cross the placenta. However, in an
O-type mother, **IgG** ABO antibodies are produced and the baby can
potentially develop [ABO hemolytic disease of the
newborn](/wiki/ABO_hemolytic_disease_of_the_newborn "ABO hemolytic disease of
the newborn").

### Clinical
applications[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Clinical applications")]

In human cells, the ABO alleles and their encoded glycosyltransferases have
been described in several oncologic conditions.[62] Using anti-GTA/GTB
monoclonal antibodies, it was demonstrated that a loss of these enzymes was
correlated to malignant bladder and oral epithelia.[63][64] Furthermore, the
expression of ABO blood group antigens in normal human tissues is dependent
the type of differentiation of the epithelium. In most human carcinomas,
including oral carcinoma, a significant event as part of the underlying
mechanism is decreased expression of the A and B antigens.[65] Several studies
have observed that a relative down-regulation of GTA and GTB occurs in oral
carcinomas in association with tumor development.[65][66] More recently, a
genome wide association study (GWAS) has identified variants in the ABO locus
associated with susceptibility to pancreatic cancer.[67]

### Clinical
marker[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Clinical marker")]

A multi-locus genetic risk score study based on a combination of 27 loci,
including the ABO gene, identified individuals at increased risk for both
incident and recurrent coronary artery disease events, as well as an enhanced
clinical benefit from statin therapy. The study was based on a community
cohort study (the Malmo Diet and Cancer study) and four additional randomized
controlled trials of primary prevention cohorts (JUPITER and ASCOT) and
secondary prevention cohorts (CARE and PROVE IT-TIMI 22).[68]

##
Pseudoscience[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ABO_blood_group_system&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Pseudoscience")]

During the 1930s, connecting [blood groups to personality
types](/wiki/Blood_types_in_Japanese_culture "Blood types in Japanese
culture") became popular in Japan and other areas of the world.[69] Studies of
this association have yet to confirm its existence definitively.[70][71]

Other popular but unsupported ideas include the use of a [blood type
diet](/wiki/Blood_type_diet "Blood type diet"), claims that group A causes
severe [hangovers](/wiki/Hangover "Hangover"), group O is associated with
perfect teeth, and those with blood group A2 have the highest [IQs](/wiki/IQ
"IQ"). Scientific evidence in support of these concepts is nonexistent.[72]
